awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Theoretical and Experimental Investigations of Inter-Molecular forces Between Environmental Pollutants and Carbon nanotubes
awd_abstract_narration:
With this collaborative award, the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Mesfin Tsige of the University of Akron and Professors Xingmao Ma and Saikat Talapatra of Southern Illinois University at Carbondale to explore solutions for removing some of the most prevalent contaminants from water using carbon-based nanomaterials.  Escalating environmental pollution problems, such as contamination of water with hazardous chemicals, and the need for proper restoration of clean environment, is a global/societal concern that warrants immediate attention.  This project endeavors to help elucidate the underlying mechanisms for the interactions between carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and organic contaminants, which is a major step forward in developing CNT-based environmental remediation method.  The project provides training to  undergraduate and graduate students in  nanofabrication, characterization and computational techniques and their applications for contamination removal from water.   The collaborative research team is also organizing an international workshop at Addis Ababa University, Ethiopia, in order to raise the global awareness of emerging water contamination issues.  

Specifically, state of the art experimental tools as well as advanced modeling are utilized to understand how different chemical contaminants interact with different architectures of CNTs, in order to identify the most suitable carbon nanotube based materials to remove hazardous chemicals from water efficiently.  The project studies (i) the nature of the adsorption for organic contaminants (in particular, the ionizable compounds) with varying molecular structures and properties, (ii) the extent to which the presence of co-contaminants as well as key environmental parameters affect the adsorption behavior of organic contaminants, and (iii) the adsorption kinetics for CNTs with different sizes or curvature and surface chemistry.  The research team plans to perform systematic adsorption studies of a wide array of organic contaminants on CNTs and conduct extensive electronic structure calculations and molecular dynamics simulations to gain insights on the intermolecular forces taking place at the liquid-solid interface when contaminants are exposed to CNTs in water. The collabortive team also plans to investigate how environmental conditions such as ionic strength and pH shift the intermolecular forces and affect the adsorption behavior of organic contaminants onto CNTs. Built on the understanding of the intermolecular forces, it should be possible to examine how different surface functionalization approaches affect the adsorption behavior of organic contaminants to CNTs, setting out defining principles for the design of of functional adsorbant nanoparticles.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative grant supported computational research in conjunction with the PI’s experimental collaborators at Southern Illinois University at Carbondale and at Texas A&M University to advance our fundamental understanding of the inter-molecular forces between environmental pollutants and carbon nanotubes. Removal of harmful chemicals from water is paramount to environmental cleanliness and safety. As such need for materials that will solve this purpose is in the forefront of environmental research that pertains to water purification. A large quantity of emerging contaminants including pharmaceuticals, personal care products, flame retardants, disinfection by-products possess oxygen-containing functional groups and can dissociate at certain environmental conditions. The ionized compounds are negatively charged, display much higher solubility than the neutral compounds, and are expected to demonstrate much lower adsorption capacity on a variety of environmental surfaces based on the calculated pH-dependent octanol water partitioning coefficient. Surprisingly, many ionized compounds displayed much stronger adsorption to several carbonaceous materials containing carboxyl or hydroxyl functional groups. Unique intermolecular forces such as the charge-assisted hydrogen bonding was ascribed as one of the very strong intermolecular forces, leading to much stronger adsorption of ionized compounds on functionalized carbonaceous materials. How the molecular size or structure of ionized compounds affect their capability to form such strong intermolecular forces and their adsorption orientation on environmental surfaces and consequently the formation of different intermolecular forces were the focus of the investigation. By combining simulation with experiment, significant new insights into the adsorption mechanisms of ionizable compounds on carbon nanotubes were obtained. We noticed that hydrophobic effect and electrostatic interactions are two predominant mechanisms for the adsorption of ionizable compounds on graphitized carbon nanotubes. When the carbon nanotubes contain oxygen-containing functional groups, strong molecular forces such indeed formed, but the forces are substantially weaker for compounds with large molecular size (e.g. more benzene rings in the structure) and compounds with additional functional groups next to the carboxylic acid functional group on the ionized compounds. Steric hindrance and altered approaching orientation of ionized compounds with more complex structures are considered two main reasons for their lower adsorption on carbon nanotubes. The PI’s experimental collaborators found that the adsorption of these compounds on house-made single-walled carbon nanotubes are much higher than multi-walled carbon nanotubes, despite the fact that the specific surface area of the single-walled carbon nanotubes is much smaller. This finding highlighted that other factors in addition to the specific surface area governs the adsorption of ionizable compounds on CNTs. Our collaborative efforts with experimental measurement and molecular simulation suggest that the bundling of single-walled carbon nanotubes generate many high energy adsorption sites, which explains the unusually high adsorption capacity of ionizable compounds on single-walled carbon nanotubes. In summary, the project generated significant mechanistic insights into the adsorption behavior of ionziable compounds on carbon nanotube surfaces, shedding more light on the investigations on the fate and transport of emerging contaminants in the environment. 

Products of this project: Through this grant, the PI directed one graduate student in the general area of soft condensed matter physics focusing on surfaces and interfaces, two undergraduate students and one high school student were also trained in computational material science.In addition, the new knowledge acquired is also being incorporated in graduate level courses. The results from this project has been disseminated to the community through peer-reviewed journals, oral presentations at national and regional conferences, and to high schools and undergraduate collegiate educational communities in the area by the PI and the students that participated in the research.
